item.title: Why would a UK judge deny fired Rockstar workers interim relief?
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 16, 2026

4 Min Read

This week, a cohort of former Rockstar employees were denied interim relief at a preliminary UK employment tribunal after alleging they were unfairly dismissed for engaging in trade union activity.

After those workers were fired in November 2025, UK trade union IWGB claimed Rockstar had perpetrated the "most blatant and ruthless act of union busting in the history of the games industry" and took legal action against the Grand Theft Auto maker. 

Rockstar said it dismissed those employees for "distributing and discussing confidential information in a public forum" in reference to a Discord channel union workers had used to support their organisation efforts. 

"This was in no way related to people’s right to join a union or engage in union activities," added Rockstar in a statement issued last year. 

The fired union workers' case against Rockstar will head to a full hearing in the UK later this year (a date has yet to be confirmed), but this week their attempt to secure interim relief in the form of wages and some working visas was quashed. People Make Games has published a terrific breakdown of the evidence presented throughout for those interested in hearing how both sides argued their case. 

IWGB described the outcome as "disappointing" but said its members remain hopeful of "winning justice" when the full hearing takes place. Rockstar welcomed the decision, which it said was "consistent" with its own position.

Related:Arc Raiders hits 12 million sales, a wild rebuttal from Bobby Kotick, and a deluge of layoffs - Patch Notes #36

But what is interim relief in the UK and how exactly does it work?

It's a question I've seen asked a number of times in the wake of this week's ruling. To provide some clarity, I reached out to Kuits specialist employment solicitor, Jake McManus, who has broken the mechanism down for our readers.

"Interim relief is rarely sought and even more rarely granted, primarily because it is only available in very limited circumstances, including where an employee alleges to be dismissed due to trade union activity or for whistleblowing," McManus told Game Developer. 

"It is not available to employees who are otherwise dismissed unfairly or in discrimination cases, both of which make up the vast majority of claims brought in the Employment Tribunal. Put simply, the circumstances in which an application for interim relief may be available just do not occur very often. Applications for interim relief must also be made within 7 days of the dismissal, so many employees will be out of time before they even consider whether an application can or should be made." 

"An unsuccessful application is not fatal for the unfair dismissal claim itself"

Related:Krafton is evaluating how its game tech may be applied to 'physical AI and robotics'

The fact that interim relief can only be sought in select circumstances, including instances of alleged union busting, explains why the fired Rockstar workers were able to seek it out. Why, though, is the bar for success during an interim relief hearing higher than the bar for a positive outcome at a full hearing? 

Simply put: a positive outcome for employees seeking interim relief could be incredibly costly for employers, especially in a climate where a backlog of tribunals means some cases could take years to reach a resolution.

"If successful, a dismissed employee can be reinstated or remain on full pay until their unfair dismissal claim is dealt with. Given the current backlog in the Tribunal system we could be talking years: an unfair dismissal claim issued today is unlikely to reach a final hearing until 2027 or 2028," added McManus. 

"It is therefore a very powerful weapon in an employee's armoury and can be very costly for an employer. What is more, if the employee goes on to lose their unfair dismissal claim then there is no obligation to reimburse the employer for any pay. Interim relief is ultimately a draconian measure for Tribunals to deploy and that is why it is rarely granted." 

Related:Microsoft, Sony, Nintendo provide joint update on player safety commitment

Discussing that threshold for success, McManus noted that interim relief will only be granted when a tribunal feels a claimant is "likely" to demonstrate the principal reason for their dismissal is one of the "very limited circumstances" detailed above—i.e. union busting or whistleblowing. That means employees must establish they have a "pretty good chance of success" when seeking interim relief as opposed to simply a "reasonable prospect of success." 

Crucially, McManus explained an unsuccessful interim relief application does not mean an unfair dismissal claim is doomed to fail—though it would certainly improve its chances of success.

"If the employee is successful with their application for interim relief then it is likely that they will be successful with the claim itself," he added. "It also signals to the parties that the claimants have a strong case, and given that the employer is affected financially by the decision to grant interim relief, it can encourage settlement. However, an unsuccessful application is not fatal for the unfair dismissal claim itself."

In the case of the interim relief tribunal between the ousted Rockstar workers and their former employer, McManus said the judge overseeing proceedings was simply unconvinced at this stage that Rockstar's decision to dismiss those employees was "most likely" due to trade union activity. As we have already established, though, a positive outcome for employees at this point in the process is rare, and McManus said the ruling doesn't mean the judge believed the dismissals were fair or that fair process was followed.

item.title: Arc Raiders hits 12 million sales, a wild rebuttal from Bobby Kotick, and a deluge of layoffs - Patch Notes #36
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 16, 2026

4 Min Read

Bobby Kotick headshot via Activision Blizzard / Patch Notes logo via Game Developer

'What a year, huh?' 'Captain, it's only January.' That is very much The Vibe two weeks into 2026. 

The headlines over the past 16 days have been dominated by layoffs layoffs, and you guessed it, even more layoffs. 

Meta and Playtika made significant cuts this week in pursuit of efficiency, AI streamlining, and all the other reasons you've heard a million times over. Elsewhere, a group of unionized Ubisoft workers who were made redundant at the beginning of the month continued to fight for their jobs over in Halifax, Canada—filing a labor complaint against the publisher in the process. 

In other (rather notable) news, we finally know how the interim relief hearing between Rockstar and the union workers it fired last year shook out, and Bobby Kotick briefly invaded our collective consciousness by way of a legal filing in which he disputes all manner of allegations related to the sale of Activision Blizzard to Microsoft (and offers a few choice theories of his own). 

Yes, dear reader, it's just another week in the wholesome world of video games. Let's have at it. 

Former Activision CEO Bobby Kotick says lawsuit opposing Microsoft-Activision deal was secretly meant to help The Embracer Group (Embracer, "humbled," denies involvement)

via Game File // Bobby Kotick has issued an extraordinary rebuttal to a lawsuit that alleges the former Activision Blizzard boss—once branded the "most hated man in video games" by Kotaku—rushed through the sale of the Call of Duty publisher to avoid dealing with sexual misconduct allegations. Responding to the ongoing lawsuit filed by Swedish pension fund AP-Fonden, Kotick and his legal team suggested the litigation is the brainchild of none other than Embracer Group, which he claims used the suit to "pave the way for Embracer to increase its foothold in the California market at the expense of Activision." This one is a must-read.

Related:Why would a UK judge deny fired Rockstar workers interim relief?

Fired Rockstar Employees in UK Lose Bid to Receive Interim Pay

via Bloomberg // A host of former Rockstar employees who claim they were fired last year for engaging in trade union activity this week failed in their attempt to secure interim pay. The ruling was described as "disappointing" by union representatives, while Rockstar welcomed the decision. The legal battle is set to continue when the case heads to a full hearing later this year.

Union files labour board complaint over closure of Ubisoft's Halifax video game studio

via CBC Canada // CWA Canada has filed a labor complaint against Ubisoft in Nova Scotia over the publisher's recent decision to shutter its studio in Halifax—announced just weeks after workers at the studio voted to unionize. The Assassin's Creed maker indicated the shut down was the result on ongoing restructuring, but CWA Canada is now claiming the termination is "directly related to the union’s recent certification."

Related:Krafton is evaluating how its game tech may be applied to 'physical AI and robotics'

'It had nothing to offer:' Halifax union lambasts Ubisoft after first talks following studio closure

via Game Developer // Sticking with Ubisoft Halifax for a second, union reps at the studio last week demanded Ubisoft present evidence to support its claim that the closure was solely a financial decision. They also called on the company to relocate impacted employees and provide more robust financial support. Yet, during the first meeting between the two parties this week, Ubisoft allegedly turning up to negotiations with "nothing to offer." 

Arc Raiders sells 12 million copies in under three months

via Game Developer // Arc Raiders has shifted 12 million copies in around three months. It's a hefty milestone that appears to have caught developer Embark by surprise thanks to a bumper holiday sales period.

Ubisoft Layoffs Continue With 55 Staff at The Division Studio Massive and Ubisoft Stockholm Now Impacted

via IGN // Seemingly eager to continue its hot streak of layoffs, Ubisoft followed the closure at Halifax by proposing cuts at two of its Swedish studios: Massive Entertainment and Ubisoft Stockholm. In a statement to IGN, the company said it expects to make 55 people redundant across both locations. Later in the week, Ubisoft confirmed it quietly made cuts at Ubisoft Abu Dhabi in November 2025.

Related:Microsoft, Sony, Nintendo provide joint update on player safety commitment

What Discord's potential IPO means for its business and the video game industry

via Game Developer // In the wake of recent reports that Discord has confidentially filed for an IPO, Nicole Carpenter reached out to a senior research analyst to better understand what going public could mean for the popular video game chat platform and the wider industry. Lots to chew on.

Meta shutters three VR studios as part of Reality Labs layoffs

via Game Developer // The company formerly known as Facebook closed a whole bunch of video game studios this week and laid off around 10 percent of employees within its VR/AR-focused Reality Labs business. The ailing division has lost billions upon billions in recent years as a result of Meta trying to brute force some form of metaverse into existence, and what does the company have to show for it? Some Ray-Bans that can record videos.
